questions.questionText: What is Next.js?
options: A React framework for full stack applications
questions.explanation: Next.js builds on React and provides routing, data fetching, and rendering features out of the box.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT a feature provided by Next.js?
questions.explanation: Next.js does not include built-in database features; it focuses on the front-end and API layer.

questions.questionText: Why is Next.js considered easier for building production apps compared to React alone?
options: It includes routing, data fetching, and optimized rendering
questions.explanation: Next.js eliminates the need for manual setup of routing and data fetching, simplifying full stack development.

questions.questionText: What is the prerequisite knowledge for learning Next.js effectively?
options: HTML, CSS, modern JavaScript, and React fundamentals
questions.explanation: Next.js builds on top of React, so a working understanding of React and JS fundamentals is required.

questions.questionText: How does routing work in Next.js?
options: You configure routes in a JSON file
You write custom routing logic in JavaScript
You create files, and routes are generated automatically
questions.explanation: Next.js automatically maps files in the `pages/` directory to routes.

questions.questionText: What is the minimum Node.js version required to use the latest version of Next.js?
questions.explanation: Next.js requires Node.js version 18.18 or later.

questions.questionText: What command is used to create a new Next.js application?
questions.explanation: `npx create-next-app@latest` is the recommended way to scaffold a Next.js project.

questions.questionText: Which configuration options were selected in the video setup?
questions.explanation: The setup included TypeScript, ESLint, and Tailwind CSS.

questions.questionText: Which command is used to start the Next.js development server?
questions.explanation: `npm run dev` runs the development server on localhost:3000.

questions.questionText: Which file should you edit to update the homepage content?
questions.explanation: In the App Router setup, `src/app/page.tsx` is the main entry for the homepage.

questions.questionText: What file defines project dependencies and scripts in a Next.js project?
questions.explanation: `package.json` defines all project dependencies and npm/yarn scripts.

questions.questionText: Which folder is created when you run `npm run dev` or `npm run build`?
questions.explanation: The `.next` folder is created to serve and build the Next.js application.

questions.questionText: Where should static assets like images and SVGs be placed?
questions.explanation: The `public` folder is meant for static assets accessible via the browser.

questions.questionText: Which folder contains the main routing logic in the App Router architecture?
questions.explanation: In the App Router structure, routing is handled in the `app` folder inside `src`.

questions.questionText: Which file defines global CSS for the application?
questions.explanation: `global.css` contains styles that apply across the entire Next.js app.

questions.questionText: What is the role of `layout.tsx` in the App Router?
options: It acts as a wrapper for shared layout elements
questions.explanation: `layout.tsx` provides a shared layout for all routes using the `children` prop.

questions.questionText: What command begins the rendering flow starting from layout to page components?
questions.explanation: `npm run dev` starts the development server and renders the layout and page.

questions.questionText: What are the two types of components in the React Server Components architecture?
questions.explanation: React Server Components architecture separates components into Server and Client components.

questions.questionText: By default, how does Next.js treat components?
questions.explanation: Next.js treats all components as server components by default.

questions.questionText: What can server components do that client components cannot?
options: Read files or fetch data from a database
questions.explanation: Server components can perform server-side tasks like reading files or accessing databases.

questions.questionText: Which directive must be added to a file to define it as a client component?
questions.explanation: The `"use client"` directive must be placed at the top of a file to make it a client component.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a feature of client components?
options: They can run only during SSR
questions.explanation: Client components can use React hooks and handle user interactions.

questions.questionText: In Next.js, where must all route files be located?
questions.explanation: Next.js requires all routes to be placed inside the 'app' folder within the source directory to map URLs correctly.

questions.questionText: What must each route file be named in Next.js to be recognized as a page?
questions.explanation: Route files must be named 'page.js' or 'page.tsx' depending on whether JavaScript or TypeScript is used to be recognized as pages.

questions.questionText: How does Next.js map URL paths to files and folders in the app directory?
options: Each file inside the app folder becomes a route
Each folder represents a segment of the URL path
Routes are configured manually in a routing file
Only files in the root app folder are routes
questions.explanation: Each folder inside the 'app' directory represents a segment of the URL path, allowing nested routes.

questions.questionText: What URL does a 'page.tsx' file inside the root 'app' folder map to?
questions.explanation: A 'page.tsx' file in the root 'app' folder automatically maps to the root URL '/' in Next.js.

questions.questionText: What happens in Next.js if a user visits a URL that does not match any route file?
options: The server returns a 404 Not Found page automatically
You must manually create a 404 page
questions.explanation: Next.js automatically returns a 404 Not Found response for URLs that don’t match any route without additional code.

questions.questionText: Which of the following best describes Next.js’s approach to routing?
options: It uses a file system-based routing with conventions
Routes are configured using JSON files
questions.explanation: Next.js favors convention over configuration by mapping file and folder structure in the 'app' folder directly to routes.

questions.questionText: Where should the 'blog' route folder be created in a Next.js project using the app router?
questions.explanation: All route folders, including 'blog', must be created inside the 'app' folder to be recognized as routes.

questions.questionText: What does the 'page.tsx' file inside the 'blog' folder represent in the URL structure?
questions.explanation: The 'page.tsx' file inside the 'blog' folder corresponds directly to the '/blog' URL route.

questions.questionText: How do you create nested routes such as '/blog/first' and '/blog/second' in Next.js app router?
options: By creating files named 'first.tsx' and 'second.tsx' inside the blog folder
By creating folders named 'first' and 'second' inside the blog folder, each containing a 'page.tsx' file
By adding query parameters to the blog route
By configuring routes manually in a config file
questions.explanation: Nested routes are created by adding folders inside the parent route folder; each folder must have its own 'page.tsx' to define that route.

questions.questionText: What will a 'page.tsx' file inside the folder 'blog/first' render when you visit '/blog/first'?
questions.explanation: A 'page.tsx' inside 'blog/first' corresponds exactly to the nested route '/blog/first' and renders its content.

questions.questionText: What is the key benefit of Next.js’s folder-based routing system for nested routes?
options: You must write complex routing code
The URLs automatically mirror your folder structure
You need to configure routes in a separate file
Routes only work at the root level
questions.explanation: Next.js automatically maps nested folders inside 'app' to URL paths, making nested routing simple and intuitive.

questions.questionText: What problem arises if you create a separate folder for each product in a product listing route?
options: It becomes hard to maintain as the number of products grows
Next.js does not allow folders for products
Each product page cannot have unique content
questions.explanation: Creating folders for each product is impractical for large numbers of products, making maintenance difficult.

questions.questionText: How does Next.js handle dynamic route segments in the app router?
options: Folders named with square brackets, e.g. [productId], create dynamic routes
By manually adding routes in a config file
questions.explanation: Folders named with square brackets indicate dynamic segments, allowing Next.js to handle routes like /products/1 or /products/abc.

questions.questionText: What prop does a Next.js page component receive to access dynamic route parameters?
questions.explanation: The page component receives a 'params' prop containing the dynamic route parameters as key-value pairs.

questions.questionText: In a server component using async/await, how do you access the dynamic segment 'productId' from the params prop?
questions.explanation: Because 'params' is a promise in server components, you await it to access 'productId'.

questions.questionText: What types of values can the dynamic segment 'productId' represent in Next.js dynamic routes?
questions.explanation: Dynamic segments can represent any string, including numbers or text like 'iPhone', making routes flexible.

questions.questionText: Which folder structure corresponds to the dynamic route '/products/[productId]' in Next.js?
questions.explanation: The dynamic route uses a folder named with square brackets inside 'products' containing a 'page.tsx' file.

questions.questionText: How do you structure folders in Next.js to handle nested dynamic routes like /products/[productId]/reviews/[reviewId]?
options: Create a folder named [productId], inside it a folder named reviews, and inside that another folder named [reviewId] each with a page.tsx
Create a single folder with the full path as its name
Create a folder named reviews inside app and put all dynamic routes there
Create a folder named [reviewId] inside products folder
questions.explanation: Nested dynamic routes require nested folders: [productId] folder, then reviews folder inside it, then [reviewId] folder with page.tsx.

questions.questionText: In a nested dynamic route component, how do you access both productId and reviewId parameters?
options: By destructuring and awaiting the params prop which contains both productId and reviewId
questions.explanation: The component receives params as a promise resolving to an object containing both dynamic parameters, which you can await and destructure.

questions.questionText: What URL path corresponds to the nested dynamic route /products/1/reviews/1?
questions.explanation: The actual URL with specific IDs replaces the dynamic segments in the nested folder structure.

questions.questionText: What is the main advantage of using nested dynamic folders in Next.js routing?
options: Allows handling multiple dynamic segments cleanly and logically
Reduces the number of files needed
questions.explanation: Nested dynamic folders enable clean, maintainable handling of multiple dynamic segments in URLs.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a correct way to visualize the folder structure for /products/[productId]/reviews/[reviewId]?
questions.explanation: The folder structure mirrors the URL segments with nested folders and dynamic segments in square brackets.

questions.questionText: What problem do catchall segments solve in Next.js routing?
options: Managing many nested routes with a single page file
questions.explanation: Catchall segments let you capture multiple nested URL segments with one dynamic route, reducing the need for many files.

questions.questionText: How do you define a catchall dynamic route folder in Next.js?
options: By naming the folder with square brackets and three dots, like [...slug]
By using curly braces around the folder name
By creating a file named catchall.js
By using a double underscore prefix, like __slug
questions.explanation: Catchall segments use the special syntax [...slug] where the three dots indicate multiple dynamic segments.

questions.questionText: What type of data does the params.slug represent in a catchall route?
options: A single string representing the full path
An array of strings representing each segment of the URL
A boolean indicating if the route is active
An object with key-value pairs of query parameters
questions.explanation: In catchall routes, params.slug is an array of strings, each representing a segment in the URL path.

questions.questionText: What happens if you want the catchall segment to also match the base path (e.g., /docs) without any segments?
options: You wrap the folder name in an extra pair of square brackets like [[...slug]]
You add an index.js file inside the catchall folder
You create a separate route for the base path
You rename the folder to base
questions.explanation: Optional catchall segments ([[...slug]]) allow matching both the base path and any nested paths.

questions.questionText: When should you use a simple page.tsx in the docs folder instead of an optional catchall route?
options: When the page UI is the same regardless of the URL segments
When the page UI depends on URL segments
When you want to handle only static routes
When you do not want to use dynamic routing
questions.explanation: Use a simple page.tsx when the UI does not change with the URL path segments; otherwise, use catchall routes.

questions.questionText: Why is using catchall segments advantageous for documentation sites?
options: It handles deeply nested documentation paths with fewer files
It improves SEO by hiding URLs
It prevents users from accessing undefined routes
questions.explanation: Catchall routes let you cover many nested paths like feature/concept/example in one dynamic route file.

questions.questionText: What is the file name convention to create a custom 404 page in Next.js app router?
questions.explanation: Next.js requires the custom 404 page to be named exactly 'not-found.tsx' (or .js) to replace the default 404.

questions.questionText: Where should you place the not-found.tsx file to customize the global 404 page?
questions.explanation: The 'not-found.tsx' file must be inside the 'app' folder to customize the global 404 page using the app router.

questions.questionText: How can you programmatically trigger the 404 page within a Next.js component?
options: By importing and calling the 'notFound' function from 'next/navigation'
questions.explanation: Next.js provides a 'notFound' function from 'next/navigation' that you can call to programmatically show the 404 page.

questions.questionText: What happens if you create a 'not-found.tsx' file inside a nested route folder like 'reviewId'?
options: It overrides the global 404 page everywhere
It creates a more specific 404 page for that route segment
questions.explanation: Next.js uses the most specific 'not-found.tsx' page for a route if it exists, allowing custom 404 pages per route segment.

questions.questionText: Why must you add the 'use client' directive at the top of a custom 404 component that uses 'usePathname' hook?
options: Because hooks can only be used in client components
Because server components don't support JSX
Because it enables static site generation
questions.explanation: React hooks like 'usePathname' only work in client components, so you need 'use client' to mark the component accordingly.

questions.questionText: What limitation does the 'not-found.tsx' component have regarding props?
options: It can only accept string props
It requires route parameters as props
questions.explanation: The 'not-found.tsx' component does not accept props; dynamic behavior should be handled using hooks like 'usePathname'.

questions.questionText: In Next.js App Router, when does a folder in the app directory become a publicly accessible route?
options: When it contains a `page.tsx` or `page.js` file
When it's included in the navigation menu
questions.explanation: A folder becomes a publicly accessible route only when a `page.tsx` or `page.js` file is added to it.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the `page.tsx` file inside a route folder?
options: It exports helper functions for the app
It determines what is rendered at that route URL
questions.explanation: The `page.tsx` file must export a default React component that renders the content for the route.

questions.questionText: What happens if you forget to add a default export in the `page.tsx` file?
options: The app will silently ignore the file
The browser will show a blank page
Next.js will throw an error saying no default export found
The file will be skipped during the build
questions.explanation: Next.js requires a default export in `page.tsx`, otherwise it throws an error indicating that no React component was found.

questions.questionText: What is one benefit of collocating components inside a route folder?
options: They help organize logic close to where it’s used
questions.explanation: Collocating components helps with organization by keeping related files close to the route they belong to.

questions.questionText: Can you organize your UI components outside the app directory in a Next.js project?
options: No, all files must be in the app directory
Yes, but only utility functions can be outside
Yes, components and logic can be kept outside, such as in a `src/components` folder
Yes, but they will not be included in the build
questions.explanation: It's perfectly valid to keep components and logic in separate folders like `src/components` for better project structure.

questions.questionText: What happens if you add a `.tsx` file (e.g., `lineChart.tsx`) to a route folder without a `page.tsx` file?
options: The route becomes accessible but shows a blank page
It results in a 404 error when accessing the route
questions.explanation: Without a `page.tsx` file in the route folder, Next.js will return a 404 because there's no default page component for the route.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of a private folder in a Next.js project?
options: To store internal files that should be excluded from routing
questions.explanation: Private folders are used to keep internal files that are not meant to be routed by Next.js.

questions.questionText: How do you mark a folder as private in a Next.js app?
options: Prefix the folder name with a dot (e.g., `.lib`)
Add a comment in a config file
Prefix the folder name with an underscore (e.g., `_lib`)
Use a `private: true` flag in the folder's metadata
questions.explanation: Next.js treats any folder starting with an underscore (e.g., `_lib`) as a private folder and excludes it from the routing system.

questions.questionText: What happens if you include a `page.tsx` file inside a private folder?
options: It is ignored by the router and not accessible via URL
It causes the app to crash
questions.explanation: Even if a `page.tsx` file is placed in a private folder, Next.js will not expose it as a route because the folder is excluded from routing.

questions.questionText: What is one of the primary benefits of using private folders?
options: They reduce bundle size by default
They help avoid accidental route exposure and maintain clean organization
questions.explanation: Private folders help developers organize internal logic and prevent routing conflicts or accidental exposure.

questions.questionText: What is the correct URL-encoded version of an underscore (`_`) character?
questions.explanation: `%5F` is the URL-encoded representation of an underscore. This can be used in URLs if you actually want the underscore to appear.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of private folders in Next.js?
options: Keeping UI logic separate from routing logic
Grouping related internal files for clarity
questions.explanation: Private folders are specifically used to prevent internal files from becoming publicly available routes.

questions.questionText: Is it mandatory to use private folders for organizing internal logic in Next.js?
options: Yes, it's the only allowed method
No, it's optional and based on developer preference
Yes, if using the app router
No, but only if using JavaScript
questions.explanation: Using private folders is optional. Developers may choose other organizational patterns, such as placing logic outside the `app` folder.

questions.questionText: What is the main purpose of route groups in Next.js?
options: To add authentication to a group of routes
To improve SEO for grouped routes
To organize files without affecting the URL structure
questions.explanation: Route groups let you group related routes for better organization while keeping the URL paths unchanged.

questions.questionText: How do you define a route group in the Next.js app directory?
options: Prefix the folder name with an underscore
Use a `.group` extension for the folder
Wrap the folder name in parentheses
Create a `group.config.js` file in the folder
questions.explanation: Next.js treats any folder wrapped in parentheses (e.g., `(auth)`) as a route group, which is ignored in the final URL structure.

questions.questionText: What happens if you group routes under a regular folder like `auth` (without parentheses)?
options: The folder name becomes part of the URL path
The routes are hidden from the public
questions.explanation: Without parentheses, Next.js includes the folder name (e.g., `auth`) in the URL path, resulting in URLs like `/auth/login`.

questions.questionText: After moving `register`, `login`, and `forgot-password` into a route group folder `(auth)`, what will be the URL for the login route?
questions.explanation: Because `(auth)` is a route group, it does not appear in the URL. The login page is accessible at `/login`.

questions.questionText: What issue can occur after moving routes into a non-group folder and how is it fixed?
options: Routes are cached; fix with `npm cache clean`
Imports break; fix with a `layout.tsx` file
Routes change path; fix by renaming the folder with parentheses
Pages won’t render; fix by using SSR
questions.explanation: When routes are nested under a regular folder, their URL path changes. Wrapping the folder name in parentheses prevents this.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is true about nesting route groups?
options: It is not supported in Next.js
It will always expose the group names in the URL
You can nest route groups within each other for deeper organization
Only one route group is allowed per project
questions.explanation: You can nest multiple route groups to organize routes further, and none of the group names will appear in the URL.

questions.questionText: What is an additional benefit of route groups besides organization?
options: They allow sharing a layout between routes without affecting the URL
They optimize images inside the folder
questions.explanation: Route groups enable shared layouts across grouped routes while preserving a clean URL structure.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of a layout in Next.js?
options: To add middleware logic to pages
To share common UI elements like headers and footers across pages
questions.explanation: Layouts allow you to reuse UI structure (like headers and footers) across multiple pages, ensuring consistency in your app.

questions.questionText: What is the name of the required layout file at the root of a Next.js app?
questions.explanation: `layout.tsx` is the required root layout file in the app directory, and Next.js will automatically recreate it if deleted.

questions.questionText: What happens if you delete the `layout.tsx` file from the app folder?
options: Next.js shows an error and stops the server
The app loses all its styles
questions.explanation: Next.js automatically recreates the root `layout.tsx` file because it's required for any app to work.

questions.questionText: Which prop must every layout component in Next.js include?
questions.explanation: The `children` prop is essential in layout components because Next.js uses it to inject the page-specific content.

questions.questionText: In the root layout, where does the content from `page.tsx` files appear?
questions.explanation: Page content is rendered in place of the `children` prop within the layout.

questions.questionText: Which of the following elements would typically go inside a layout file?
questions.explanation: Header and footer elements are common UI components that are shared across pages and fit naturally in a layout.

questions.questionText: How does the layout file affect navigation between routes like `/about` or `/profile`?
options: It hides the header and footer on route change
It ensures the layout (e.g., header/footer) remains constant across these routes
questions.explanation: The root layout remains in place and only the children content changes, providing a consistent structure during navigation.

questions.questionText: What is a nested layout in Next.js?
options: A layout that overrides the root layout
A layout used for dynamic routing only
A layout placed inside a subfolder to apply to specific pages
A layout defined in the public folder
questions.explanation: Nested layouts are placed in specific folders (like `product/[id]/layout.tsx`) to apply layout logic to only that part of the app.

questions.questionText: In Next.js, what does the `children` prop represent in a nested layout component?
options: The content of the specific page inside that folder
questions.explanation: In nested layouts, the `children` prop represents the content from the `page.tsx` file within the same folder.

questions.questionText: Which of the following best describes how Next.js renders nested layouts?
options: Only the nested layout is rendered, replacing the root layout
The nested layout wraps the root layout
The root layout renders first, then the nested layout, then the page content
The layout is rendered only on the initial load
questions.explanation: Next.js renders layouts from the root down: first the root layout, then any nested layout, and finally the page content.

questions.questionText: What visual change occurs when you navigate to `/products/1` if a nested layout is added in `products/[id]/layout.tsx`?
options: The entire layout changes, removing the root layout
A section like 'Featured Products' appears between header and footer
The page content fails to render
questions.explanation: The nested layout can add extra sections such as 'Featured Products' while still being wrapped by the root layout's header and footer.

questions.questionText: What is the correct way to create a nested layout in Next.js?
options: Add a layout.tsx file inside the specific folder
Use a special layout wrapper in `page.tsx`
Define the layout in `app/layout.tsx` using route conditions
Use the `_app.js` file to wrap the page
questions.explanation: To create a nested layout, you place a `layout.tsx` file directly in the relevant subfolder.

questions.questionText: Why would you want to use nested layouts in a Next.js project?
options: To apply specialized UI for certain routes without affecting the whole app
To dynamically change the root layout
questions.explanation: Nested layouts help you create route-specific layouts, like a unique layout for product pages, without altering the rest of the app.

questions.questionText: What part of the layout structure gets replaced when navigating between pages that use the same nested layout?
options: Both layouts get re-rendered from scratch
questions.explanation: When moving between routes that share the same nested layout, only the content from the `page.tsx` file changes — the layout stays in place.
